until.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: if something happens until a particular time, it continues and then stops at that time
until.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: The ticket is valid until March.
He waited until she had finished speaking.
Until recently, Anna worked as a teacher in Japan.
Up until last year, they didn’t even own a car.
until.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: GRAMMAR: Choosing the right tense
until.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0: You use the simple present tense with until
I will wait until I hear from you
until.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1: Don’t use ‘will’ in the clause after until
I will wait until I will hear from you
until.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2: You can also use the present perfect tense with until
I will wait until I have heard from you
Stir until the sugar has dissolved
until I will have heard from you
until the sugar will have dissolved
until.translation[0].note_box[0].items[3: You can also use the past perfect tense with until
I waited until the train had left the station
until.translation[0].note_box[1].heading: USAGE: Until now, so far
until.translation[0].note_box[1].items[0: You usually use until now when a situation has just ended or changed
I have never thought about it until now  (=but now I have thought about it)
until.translation[0].note_box[1].items[1: You use so far when a situation has not changed
We don't have any news about him so far
We don't have any news about him until now
until.translation[0].note_box[2].items[0: In everyday English, people often say till rather than until:
I’ll wait till you get back.
